Package Graphics

Class GraphicsObject

java.lang.Object
Graphics.GraphicsObject
All Implemented Interfaces:
Cloneable
Direct Known Subclasses:
Circle, Line, Oval, Point, Polygon, Rectangle
public abstract class GraphicsObject extends Object implements Cloneable
This is the base class for all graphics objects. Implementation notes:

Zelle's library defines a clone() method for creating a copy of an existing object. Unfortunately, Java already defines a Object.clone() method which does the same thing, but is not type-safe; the result needs to be explicitly cast to the proper type. I've chosen instead to just have every class define a copy constructor that creates a copy of the object in an undrawn state.

Every derived class must, at a minimum, provide its own implementation of the doDraw() and doMove() methods. The doDraw() is responsible for just drawing the object in its current state. It is called when the object is first created, and when the entire display list is redrawn.

doMove() only needs to modify the coordinates of the object; the redrawing is done by the base class.

Derived classes should also optionally override setFill, setOutline, and setWidth if they can support those operations. The versions of setFill and setOutline that take color names are handled in this class, and result in a call to the corresponding function that takes a ColorRGB object.

The undraw() function is handled entirely within the GraphicsObject class.

  • Field Details

    • win

      protected GraphWin win
      The GraphWin this object is drawn on.

      An object may only be drawn in one window at a time. If win is null, the object is not currently drawn in any window.

  • Constructor Details

    • GraphicsObject

      protected GraphicsObject()
      Create a GraphicsObject.

      This is protected because a GraphicsObject should never be created. Only derived classes are at all useful.

  • Method Details

    • setFill

      public void setFill(ColorRGB color)
      Set the fill color for this object.

      Derived classes override this if and only if they support filled objects.

      Parameters:
      color - A ColorRGB object specifying the fill color.

    • setFill

      public final void setFill(String color)
      Set the fill color for this object, using an X11 color name.

      This translates the name to an ColorRGB and calls the setFill() with that.

      Parameters:
      color - An X11 color name specifying the fill color.

    • setOutline

      public void setOutline(ColorRGB color)
      Set the outline color for this object.

      Every derived class should probably override this.

      Parameters:
      color - A ColorRGB object specifying the outline color.

    • setOutline

      public final void setOutline(String color)
      Set the outline color for this object, using an X11 color name.

      This translates the name to an ColorRGB and calls the setOutline() with that.

      Parameters:
      color - An X11 color name specifying the outline color.

    • setWidth

      public void setWidth(int pixels)
      Set the line width to use when drawing this object.

      Derived classes override this if and only if they support an outline width.

      Parameters:
      pixels - The width, in pixels, of the outline.

    • doDraw

      protected abstract void doDraw(Graphics g)
      Draw the object.

      This must be overridden by every derived class. It is called when the object is first drawn, and every time the display list is redrawn.

      Parameters:
      g - The graphics object to draw into.

    • draw

      public final void draw(GraphWin win)
      Draw the object.

      The object is also added to a list of objects (the display list) that are redrawn whenever the window is redrawn.

      Derived classes cannot override this function.

      Parameters:
      win - The GraphWin object to draw this object on.

    • doMove

      protected abstract void doMove(double dx, double dy)
      Move the object.

      Note that the move is specified as a delta, not an absolute position.

      This must be overridden by every derived class. It is called when move() is called for the object. The derived class should only modify the object position; the actual drawing is done by the base class.

      Parameters:
      dx - The x distance to move.
      dy - The y distance to move.

    • move

      public final void move(double dx, double dy)
      Move the object.

      Note that the move is specified as a delta, not an absolute position. Calling this function will always force a redraw of the entire window in order to maintain the z-ordering of objects.

      Parameters:
      dx - The x distance to move.
      dy - The y distance to move.

    • undraw

      public final void undraw()
      Undraw the object.

      Calling this function will always force a redraw of the entire window in order to maintain the z-ordering of objects.
